original_title: LB Finance to raise Rs. 20 billion through debentures; selling pressure brings down indices
original_body_lines: L B Finance will issue a hundred million senior debentures and a hundred million subordinated debentures, to raise a total of Rs 20 billion, CSE sources said.

50,000,000 listed, rated, senior, unsecured, redeemable debentures will be issued, the finance company sources said, with an option to issue a further 30,000,000 in the event of an oversubscription of the initial issue, and another 20,000,000 if there’s an oversubscription of the second tranche.

Amid these developments, CSE indices at the outset yesterday picked up but during the latter part of the trading session selling pressure was noted and subsequently the All Share Price Index went down by 68.34 points while the S and P SL20 rose by 5.59 points. Turnover stood at Rs 7.95 billion with 17 crossings.

The top seven crossings were reported in Cargills Ceylon Ltd. where 560,000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 420 million; its shares traded at 750, Commercial Bank 1.48 million shares crossed to the tune of Rs 291 million; its shares traded at Rs 196, CT Holdings 422,00 shares crossed for Rs 274 million; its shares traded at Rs 651, Colombo Dockyard 1.9 million shares crossed to the tune of Rs 246 million; its shares sold at Rs 134, Cargills Bank 24 million shares crossed to the tune of Rs 241 million; its shares traded at Rs 10.30, Aitken Spence 50000 shares crossed for Rs 111 million; its shares traded at Rs 171, TJ Lanka 1.8 million shares crossed for Rs 75 million; its shares fetched Rs 41.50.

In the retail market top seven companies that mainly contributed to the turnover were; Cargills Bank Rs 333 million (32.8 million shares traded), Pan Asia Power Rs 259 million (8.3 million shares traded), Sampath Bank Rs 217 million (1.5 million shares traded), JKH Rs 207 million (9.56 million shares traded), Haycarb Rs 181 million (1.6 million shares traded), DFCC Rs 172 million (one million shares traded) and Overseas Realty Rs 129 million (three million shares traded). During the day 247 million share volumes changed hands in 45000 transactions.
It is said that the banking sector led the market, especially Commercial Bank. The manufacturing sector also performed well, especially JKH.
Yesterday the rupee opened at Rs 302.42/48 to the US dollar, from Rs 302.45/55 Friday, while bond yields were broadly steady after the market opened quiet, dealers said.
A bond maturing on 15.09.2027 was quoted at 8.80/90 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.02.2028 was quoted at 9.00/10 percent, down from 9.05/10 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.09.2029 was quoted at 9.65/72 percent.
A bond maturing on 01.07.2030 was quoted at 9.75/85 percent.
An auction of Rs 33,500 million Treasury bills is scheduled for Wednesday.
